ITEMS OF INTEREST.

A meeting increasing the costs was held at Rat Portage.

Fifteen hundred sheep arrived at Winnipeg from Montana.

The North American Methodist Conference met here last week.

Black walnut has been planted on Garibaldi Island for an experiment.

Chili peppers are said to be used extensively by the Indians.

Gillmore's extensive arable land settlement on the Ottawa, were destroyed by fire.

Sir A. T. Hamilton has left Rat Portage, N.W.T., and is on his way back to Winnipeg from Montana.

Mr. Alexander Mitchell, a leading citizen of Hamilton, and an old-time Mason, is dead.

The Highland city council has voted against the question bail to the Woman's medical college.

Gamour Reid, R.S., Eastern Shore, was badly injured through his horse being killed at Hopkin's Point, Kelly's Island.

Two capitalists from New York are in the Kingdom city, thus taking up a proposed timber company.

Five men employed on Michael Gayvin at the Hamilton bridge works.

He got off with a broken leg.

Captain Robert Irwin for Levas and Graveline, South Carolina.

The widow of the millionaire expressman, Frank C. Fairchild, was assassinated at Buffalo, Miss. Fager's son, Capt. C. St. Boniface, Miss., married in to be run single at or near the scene where his wife was murdered.

Two scientists from Chicago, Mr. Smith and Dr. Hill, went into the woods in search of gold.

Capt. Astridek of the Montana Police, with a party of men, arrived last Sunday, and secured several prisoners.

The July 11th court, held at Ripon, examined county court, held at Ripon on July 11th.

The following statement shows the proposed act approved by the Board of Commissioners, July 11th.

The Board of Commissioners appointed J.J. Campbell, J.P., on the bench, Charles Cardinal was brought up on a warrant charging him with disorderly conduct.

Mr. Joseph Houseman, chairman of the Ripon board of aldermen, laid before the assessors, also conveying the death of Judge E. A. Miller, now of Chicago.

A large quantity of oil is being shipped from the Cowichan Bay and other places for the purpose of lighting the lamp in the church at Cowichan Bay.

At a recent court, held at Innisfail, on August 5th, Mr. Lindsay Powell, on his appearance to plead to charges of assault of Lewis Albert, the settler of the town, was ordered to appear next day.

Miss Kate McCrady, recently ran the Canadian sides and shot a bull, but the animal escaped without striking the white feather at this place.

A girl of eighteen escaped from her father's house at Kamiballi, London County, though he had seventy pounds and winner over her head.

The St. Adam's Band, under the direction of Miss Alliston, gave a concert to benefit the Band parents.

Two young boys of Parcells, chief of police at Calgary, have been arrested and placed in custody at Yankton, while on a fishing expedition.

The annual subscription of the Chamber of Commerce of Toronto, which two weeks ago was raised by taxation, and one month later by the sale of tickets by William Macdonald, has been greatly increased.

Mr. Nuttall at Rat Portage and conveyed to Winnipeg, have been committed for trial, tried being Mrs. Olga McMillan.

An elegant horse belonging to Miss Ellen Shaw was stolen from her stable on July 1st, and was hanging on the fence in front of her house.

THE PRINCE ALBERT TIMES

WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 22, 1883

FIRE PROTECTION.

We have before alluded to the requirements of our town in the matter of fire protection. When a fire arises, it only wants a quantity of combustible material and a fair wind to make it an uncontrollable enemy. Prince Albert is just now situated in such a manner as would ensure its speedy destruction in the event of a fire. The river bed forms a channel through which there is a continual current of wind, and the long continuous rows of wooden houses along the main streets supply a fire with all needed material when ever it takes place. The fire at the Transportation Company's wood yard on Friday last is a warning which should not pass unheeded. If nothing more was to be done we should at least organize a good bucket company. The mere advantage of having buckets in readiness, and not every body knowing his proper place would in itself be of immense advantage.

CAREY'S DOOM.

The news of Carey's doom seems to have created very little comment. It was what everyone expected. Notwithstanding the precautions of the Government his avenging fellow conspirators dodged his steps. When he reached a chance to kill him, became indignant and ran away the lives of his companions in iniquity he becomes despicable in the eyes of all mankind. This was the position in the case of the in former case. His charge has been so redeeming because he was an organizer and leader of assassins—the men who expanded their crime upon the gallows were merely tools. They had no ambition to acquire the characters of men, from a few stolen ideas of patriotism, take their lives in their hands, believing that by doing so they can serve their country and race, but the realising of a cynical villain who trades on the patriotism of those more honest, if more ignorant than himself, and then Judas-like betrays them and cheats the hangman by turning informer is a traitor to humanity, and of all crimes most detestable. The traitor's death which Carey met was but a fitting termination to a most infamous career.

THE LIBEL SUIT.

Our readers will remember that in the issues of the Prince Albert Times of the 14th and 21st of last March, two articles appeared reflecting upon the private and social standing of our former editor Mr Fitz Cochrane. On account of the importance of these articles Mr. Cochrane brought an action of libel against the proprietors of this paper, and the case was entered for trial at the last May sitting of the District Court. The District Court was adjourned until the next October sittings at our request on the ground of the absence of material witnesses. The length of time which has elapsed since the appearance of these articles, has to a great extent had an ameliorating effect upon Mr. Cochrane and ourselves, and we have agreed to bury the hatchet, and settle our differences without going into court to judge and jury. One part of the compromise being a public withdrawal of the charges contained in the articles referred to, and the payment of costs. We think the suit therefore now subsides with charge, and regret that they were ever published, and trust that Mr. Cochrane has not been injured in any way by their publication.

AN AMATEUR YACHTSMAN.

The Wishing that Mr. and Mrs. Spoozydike, who were visiting Prince Albert, had been able to purchase a fishing boat.

"My dear," exclaimed Mr. Spoozydike, "how I long to be able to take my wife and children out on the lake! But alas, we have not yet purchased a boat."

"Ah, but you will soon have the opportunity," replied Mrs. Spoozydike. "I have heard that there is a boat for sale at the auction next week."

"That's wonderful news!" exclaimed Mr. Spoozydike. "We shall certainly purchase it then."

To the Editor of The Times.

Sir, If your space permits I will be obliged by your inserting a few remarks prompted by the publication in your issue of the last week of a report of an examination before trial before Mr Cameron's Fiddler. While I admit that the report in the form given is not altogether accurate and sensible paragraphs, I venture to question the wisdom of treating outbreaks of that nature from the stand point of fact. That other considerations are based on the fear that strong tends to encourage stronger, which may indeed be true, which is to be feared is hardly only too prevalent in certain quarters, and which is especially dangerous in view of the present stage of the question. ginger, bar oil, etc., epimolus generally.
